facts.text: Workman was charge-sheeted for riotous and disorderly behaviour for assaulting tea maker Shri U. M. Abdul Kadar on May 29, 1965, inside the factory.

anchor.surface_text: The workman companycerned was charge-sheeted in respect of riotous and disorderly behaviour for having assaulted a tea maker Shri U. M. Abdul Kadar on May 29, 1965, inside the factory.

facts.text: Departmental enquiry was held and workman was given every opportunity to participate.

anchor.surface_text: A departmental enquiry was held wherein, it is said, he was given every opportunity to fully participate.

facts.text: Workman was found guilty of misconduct by the domestic tribunal and dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: He was found guilty of misconduct by the domestic tribunal and was accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Scheme of gratuity was in force and not challenged by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: There was a scheme of gratuity in force, which was and is number challenged by the respondent.

facts.text: Clause 4 of gratuity scheme provides that disputes on gratuity for dismissed workman referred to labour court.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 4 of that scheme, which is called Terms of Agreement, provides that if a dispute arises regarding a claim for payment of gratuity of a workman who has been dismissed for misconduct, such a dispute shall be referred to the labour companyrt having jurisdiction, for decision.

facts.text: Dispute arose regarding payment of gratuity and was referred to Labour Court.

anchor.surface_text: As a dispute arose with regard to the payment of gratuity, the matter was referred to the Labour companyrt.

facts.text: Worker was not paid gratuity on dismissal despite request.

anchor.surface_text: The worker was number paid gratuity on dismissal, in spite of making a request for the same.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme applicable to this estate.

anchor.surface_text: There is a gratuity scheme applicable to this estate and as per the terms of the scheme

facts.text: Worker put in 18 years of service.

anchor.surface_text: The worker has put in 18 years of service and as such he is entitled

facts.text: Entitled to gratuity at 15 days wages per completed year based on last drawn wage rate.

anchor.surface_text: to get at the rate of 15 days wages based on last draw wage rate for every companypleted years of service.

facts.text: Management filed reply setting out facts and circumstances of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: In reply, which was filed by the management, the facts which have been set out above and the circumstances in which the dismissal was directed, were fully given.

facts.text: No dispute before Labour Court that dismissal was for misconduct of riotous and disorderly manner and assault on tea maker supervisor.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Labour companyrt, there seems to have been numberdispute whatsoever that the dismissal of the respondent workman was on account of misconduct companysisting, of behaving in a riotous and disorderly manner and having assaulted a tea maker  supervisor .

facts.text: Labour Court made an award granting gratuity (inferred from appeal).

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 698 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 10. 1967 of the Labour Court,  Kerala State , Quilon, Camp at Calicut, in Industrial Dispute No. 70 of 1965 published in the Kerala Govt. Gazette No. 39 dated 3-10-67. B. Pal,, Bhuvanesh Kumari and 0. C. Mathur, for the appellant. S. Nambiyar, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GROVER, J.-This is an appeal by special leave from An award of the Labour Court, Quilon  Kerala State .

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside the Labour Court award.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is number necessary to send the matter to the labour companyrt, because the facts were number in dispute before it. For the reasons given above, the appeal is allowed and the award of the Labour Court is set aside.

facts.text: Workman not entitled to gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: It is hereby declared that the companycerned workman will number be entitled to the gratuity earned by him.

facts.text: Misconduct involved riotous or disorderly behaviour, act of violence.

anchor.surface_text: The workman companycerned was charge-sheeted in respect of riotous and disorderly behaviour for having assaulted a tea maker Shri U. M. Abdul Kadar on May 29, 1965, inside the factory. A departmental enquiry was held wherein, it is said, he was given every opportunity to fully participate. He was found guilty of misconduct by the domestic tribunal and was accordingly dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It was laid down in Delhi Cloth General Mills Co., Ltd., Workmen and Others, etc.  2  that the object of having a gratuity scheme is to provide a retiring benefit to workmen who have rendered long and unblemished service to the employer and thereby companytributed to the prosperity of the employer, and it is, therefore, number companyrect to say that numbermisconduct however grave, .-may number be visited with forfeiture of gratuity. Misconduct companyld be of three kinds,  1  technical misconduct which leaves numbertrail of indiscipline,  2  misconduct resulting in damage to the employers property which might be companypensated by,forfeiture of gratuity or part thereof, and  3  ,serious misconduct such as acts of violence against the management or other employees or riotous or disorderly behaviour in or near the place of employment, which, though number directly causing damage, is companyducive to grave indiscipline. The first should involve numberforfeiture, the second may involve forfeiture of the amount equal to the loss directly suffered by the employer in companysequence of the misconduct and the third will entail forfeiture of gratuity due to the workman.

concepts.interpretation: Gratuity forfeiture depends on type of misconduct: (1) technical - no forfeiture; (2) damage to property - forfeiture equal to loss; (3) serious like violence, riotous/disorderly behaviour - complete forfeiture.

anchor.surface_text: In yet another case in Remington Rand of India Ltd. v. The Workmen, 3  one of the questions was whether a provision can be made in a gratuity scheme that if the misconduct is a gross one, involving violence, riotous behaviour, etc., the qualifying period should be limited to fifteen years of companytinuous service. The earlier decision in Delhi Cloth and General Mills Ltd., was discussed and reference was made to it. The Court expressed agreement with the decision in the earlier case that matters which had impact on the discipline and the working of the companycern, require a different treatment in the matter of forfeiture of gratuity.

concepts.interpretation: Agrees with Delhi Cloth Mills that gross misconduct involving violence or riotous behaviour warrants different treatment including possible forfeiture.

issues.text: Whether the workman dismissed for riotous and disorderly behaviour by assaulting a colleague inside the factory is entitled to gratuity

anchor.surface_text: The point before us is simple. The workman concerned was charge-sheeted in respect of riotous and disorderly behaviour for having assaulted a tea maker Shri U. M. Abdul Kadar on May 29, 1965, inside the factory. A departmental enquiry was held wherein, it is said, he was given every opportunity to fully participate.

issues.text: Whether the misconduct alleged against the worker disentitles him to gratuity given absence of moral turpitude or financial loss to the company

anchor.surface_text: The allegations of misconduct levelled against the worker in this case cannot be considered to be one which by its nature disentitles the worker to claim gratuity. Even if the allegation is true the same does number involve any question of moral turpitude or. cause any financial loss to the companypany.

issues.text: Whether the Labour Court failed to apply its mind to the nature and degree of misconduct warranting remission for fresh decision

holdings.text: The concerned workman is not entitled to the gratuity earned by him because he was dismissed for gross misconduct consisting of riotous and disorderly behaviour and assault.

anchor.surface_text: The point before us is simple. The workman concerned was charge-sheeted in respect of riotous and disorderly behaviour for having assaulted a tea maker Shri U. M. Abdul Kadar on May 29, 1965, inside the factory. A department

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of misconduct not disputed; applies Delhi Cloth Mills classification where category 3 serious misconduct (riotous/disorderly behaviour, violence) entails complete forfeiture of gratuity.

holdings.text: The misconduct of riotous and disorderly behaviour and assault on tea maker supervisor constitutes serious misconduct of the third category under Delhi Cloth Mills doctrine warranting complete forfeiture of gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: It was laid down in Delhi Cloth General Mills Co., Ltd., Workmen and Others, etc.  2  that the object of having a gratuity scheme is to provide a retiring benefit to workmen who have rendered long and unblemished service to the employer and thereby contributed to the prosperity of the employer, and it is, therefore, not correct to say that no misconduct however grave, may not be visited with forfeiture of gratuity. Misconduct could be of three kinds,  1  technical misconduct which leaves no trail of indiscipline,  2  misconduct resulting in damage to the employers property which might be compensated by,forfeiture of gratuity or part thereof, and  3  ,serious misconduct such as acts of violence against the management or other employees or riotous or disorderly behaviour in or near the place of employment, which, though not directly causing damage, is conducive to grave indiscipline. The first should involve no forfeiture, the second may involve forfeiture of the amount equal to the loss directly suffered by the employer in consequence of the misconduct and the third will entail forfeiture of gratuity due to the workman.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applies Delhi Cloth Mills three-category classification of misconduct to undisputed facts of riotous/disorderly conduct and assault as violence conducive to indiscipline.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to remit the matter to the Labour Court as the facts were not in dispute before it.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondents has not been able to show how the rule laid down in the Delhi Cloth Mills case would not be applicable if the concerned workman was guilty of the kind of misconduct mentioned above. His sole contention has been that the Labour court did not apply its mind to the nature and degree of the misconduct committed, and, therefore, the matter should be remitted to that court for a decision in accordance with law. In our opinion, it is not necessary to send the matter to the labour court, because the facts were not in dispute before it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed facts before Labour Court suffice for application of law without need for fresh consideration.

holdings.text: The principle of forfeiture of gratuity for gross misconduct like riotous/disorderly conduct or violence laid down in Delhi Cloth Mills has been incorporated in section 4(6)(b) of the Payment of Gratuity Act.

anchor.surface_text: significant that in S. 4  6   b  of the Payment of Gratuity Act, it has been provided as follows the gratuity payable to an employee shall be wholly forfeited i  if the services of such employee have been terminated for his riotous or disorderly conduct or any other act of violence on his part. Although the provisions of this statute would not govern the decision of the present case, the importance of the enactment lies in the fact that the principle which was laid down in the Delhi Cloth Mills case with regard to forfeiture of gratuity in the event of commission of gross misconduct of the nature mentioned above, has been incorporated in the statute itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision mirrors judicial principle from Delhi Cloth Mills, though statute inapplicable here; promotes industrial harmony and public policy.

holdings.text: Such a rule of forfeiture for gross misconduct is conducive to industrial harmony and in consonance with public policy.

anchor.surface_text: Even otherwise, such a rule is conducive to industrial harmony and is in consonance with public policy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even apart from statute, forfeiture rule for serious misconduct supports discipline and public policy.

anchor.surface_text: It was laid down in Delhi Cloth General Mills Co., Ltd., Workmen and Others, etc.  2  that the object of having a gratuity scheme is to provide a retiring benefit to workmen who have rendered long and unblemished service to the employer and thereby contributed to the prosperity of the employer, and it is, therefore, not correct to say that no misconduct however grave, may not be visited with forfeiture of gratuity. Misconduct could be of three kinds,  1  technical misconduct which leaves no trail of indiscipline,  2  misconduct resulting in damage to the employers property which might be compensated by,forfeiture of gratuity or part thereof, and  3  ,serious misconduct such as acts of violence against the management or other employees or riotous or disorderly behaviour in or near the place of employment, which, though not directly causing damage, is conducive to grave indiscipline. The first should involve no forfeiture, the second may involve forfeiture of the amount equal to the loss directly suffered by the employer in consequence of the misconduct and the third will entail forfeiture of gratuity due to the workman.
For the reasons given above, the appeal is allowed and the award of the Labour Court is set aside. It is hereby declared that the concerned workman will number be entitled to the gratuity ea

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondents has not been able to show how the rule laid down in the Delhi Cloth Mills case would not be applicable if the concerned workman was guilty of the kind of misconduct mentioned above. His sole contention has been that the Labour court did not apply its mind to the nature and degree of the misconduct committed, and, therefore, the matter should be remitted to that court for a decision in accordance with law. In our opinion, it is not necessary to send the matter to the labour court, because the facts were not in dispute before it.
For the reasons given above, the appeal is allowed and the award of the Labour Court is set aside. It is hereby declared that the concerned workman will number be entitled to the gratuity ea
